verses.text: The Elder to the beloved Gaius, whom I love in the Truth.
Beloved, I pray that in every respect your journey may be smooth and your body healthy, just as your inner life is journeying well.
For I was overjoyed when brothers arrived and testified to your integrity—to how you are living in accordance with the Truth.
I have no greater joy than this: to hear that my own children are living their lives in the Truth.
Beloved, you are acting faithfully in whatever you work you do for the brothers, even when they are strangers to you.
They have testified to your love before the gathered community. You will do well to provide for their journey in a manner worthy of the God we serve.
For they went out for the sake of The Name, accepting nothing from the pagans.
We, therefore, are obligated to sustain such people, so that we may become fellow-workers for the Truth.
I wrote something to the community, but Diotrephes, who loves to be the one in charge, does not acknowledge our authority.

For this reason, if I come, I will bring up the works he is doing—spreading malicious nonsense against us. And not satisfied with this, he refuses to welcome the brothers himself; he even hinders those who want to do so and expels them from the community.
Beloved, do not imitate what is evil but what is good. The one who does good is from God; the one who does evil has not seen God.
Demetrius has received a good testimony from everyone and from the Truth itself. We also add our testimony, and you know that our testimony is true.
I had many things to write to you, but I do not wish to write them to you with ink and reed-pen.
Instead, I hope to see you very soon, and we will speak mouth to mouth.
Peace be with you. The friends greet you. Greet the friends there, each by name.

chapters.notes:
**"The Elder" (v. 1)**: The Greek *ho presbyteros* is used here as a specific title of authority within the Johannine community, rather than merely an indication of advanced age.

**"Journey may be smooth... journeying well" (v. 2)**: The Greek *euodousthai* literally means "to have a good way" or "to have a successful journey." While often translated as "prosper," the word carries the nuance of things going well for someone as they move through life. The translation preserves the link between the physical "journey" and the "journeying" of the *psychē* (inner life/soul).

**"Living" (v. 3, 4)**: The Greek *peripateis* (literally "walking") is a common Semitic idiom (reflecting the Hebrew *halakhah*) referring to a person's conduct, lifestyle, and moral path. "Living" or "living out" captures the active, lifestyle-oriented nature of the term better than the literal "walk."

**"The Truth" (v. 1, 3, 4, 8, 12)**: In the Johannine writings, *alētheia* is more than factual accuracy; it is a near-technical term for the reality of God revealed in Christ and the lifestyle that flows from it. 

**"Provide for their journey" (v. 6)**: The Greek *propempsas* means more than just saying goodbye; it refers to the practice of providing travelers with food, money, and companions to ensure they reach their next destination safely.

**"The Name" (v. 7)**: The Greek *tou onomatos* is used absolutely here. To the original audience, this was a clear reference to the name and authority of Jesus, echoing the Jewish practice of referring to Yahweh as *HaShem* ("The Name") to avoid speaking the divine name.

**"Sustain" (v. 8)**: The Greek *hypolambanein* carries the sense of "taking up" or "supporting from below." It implies a duty of hospitality and material support.

**"Who loves to be the one in charge" (v. 9)**: The Greek *philoprōteuōn* is a rare and biting term for someone who is power-hungry or loves to be first.

**"Malicious nonsense" (v. 10)**: The verb *phlyarōn* refers to empty, senseless, or gossiping talk. Diotrephes is not making substantive charges; he is "talking trash" or "babbling" against the Elder.

**"Mouth to mouth" (v. 14)**: This is a literal rendering of the Greek *stoma pros stoma*. It is a Semitic idiom (found in the LXX in Numbers 12:8) for intimate, direct communication without intermediaries or tools. "Face to face" is the modern equivalent, but "mouth to mouth" preserves the specific flavor of the original text.

**"Friends" (v. 15)**: The use of *philoi* ("friends") instead of "brothers" or "saints" is unique to 3 John in the closing of a New Testament letter, perhaps indicating a closer-knit or more embattled circle of associates.
